Award.AwardTitle: Constraints on the Composition of the Subducting Oceanic Crust in the Northwest Pacific Ocean Basin
Award.AbstractNarration: Geochemical mass balances are crucial for the understanding of how elements partition between the crust and mantle, especially where ocean crust is recycled from the seafloor back into the mantle during subduction. This research is a first-of-its-kind, proof-of-concept study that uses a novel, new, statistical approach to understand the extent to which the chemistry of rocks, that get subducted, comes back to earth's surface as magmas and gases in volcanic arcs like Japan and the Aleutians. The approach taken combines geoinformatics and data-mining of large compendiums of geochemical and isotopic data for seafloor volcanic rocks and sediments with calculations of potential, common, ocean crust, compositional end members. Data from volcanic arcs in the western and northern Pacific (Marianas through the Aleutians) will be analyzed, and quality-controlled compendiums of data will be compiled for analysis. Broader impacts of the work include support of a PI from groups under-represented in the sciences and undergraduate student training in geoinformatics. The work is relevant to the NSF-funded MARGINS and Ocean Drilling Program missions and science plans. Resulting data will be publicly available through the NSF-funded PetDB data portal and data archive.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we compiled previously published data on the chemical composition of arc volcanic rocks found in volcanic arcs around northern Pacific Ocean. Volcanic arcs form in so-called 'subduction zones'. These are zones of plate collision, where one lithospheric plate - which is a tens of kilometer thick package of crust and underlying mantle - is dragged below (or ‘subducted’) beneath another lithospheric plate. Chains of arc volcanoes are constructed on the overriding plate at about 100-120 km depth above the subducting lithospheric slab. A portion of the subducted rock materials is returned (‘recycled’) to the volcanic arcs, which means it is released from the slab beneath the volcanic arcs and reaches the Earth surface again via the volcanism, usually within a few million years.

The compositional link between the downgoing slab and volcanic arc was a very exciting discovery in Earth sciences. By now, there have been many studies in volcanic arcs exploring the efficiency and strength of this link. These studies rely heavily on the ratios of radiogenic isotopes of Pb, Sr, Nd and Hf, which allow for tracking the pathway of the rock material from its subduction in the collision zones to its re-emergence in the volcanic arcs.

In order to evaluate the published data that accumulated in the course of 30 years, we compiled them now into a single database for comparative evaluation. Comparative evaluation of data from multiple volcanic arcs is a powerful tool in better constraining understanding the material fluxes from slab to arc as those depend on many factors. Because this is a large task, we limited our first studies on volcanic arcs located around the northern Pacific ocean, starting with Luzon in the west and going from Taiwan, the Izu Bonin Mariana arcs, the Ryukyu and Japan arcs, to the Kuriles, Kamchatka, the Aleutians and Alaska arcs all the way to the Cascades and to Mexico. We compiled a total of 4452 samples sets, about half of which (n=2236) contain isotope Sr-Nd-Pb-Hf data. We also collected information on the analytical quality and linked the geochemical data to their volcanic sources. In order to manage this amount of data we employed a relational data base that is designed for the management of data linked to multiple variables.

Our first results show that the Pb isotope ratios are particularly useful for tracing the contribution of the subducting slab to the arcs because most of the Pb in the arcs is derived from the slab. Pb isotopes are so sensitive that they allow even for distinguishing between the different components of the slab, such as the igneous layer of the subducting slab and a sedimentary layer, which have different isotope compositions. Moreover, in combination with high quality major and trace elements the Pb isotope data show that the volcanic arcs involve much more recycled slab material than previously thought. This latter inference emphasizes the importance of further evaluating the role of volcanic arcs in shaping the global climate that is known to be influenced by arc volcanism as well.

To date, we have published the results of our projects on one paper and several presentations at international conferences.  We will make shortly available our compiled data to the community. The project provided training for three undergraduate students, furthered the career of a female scientist with a disability and is fostering collaboration with scientists from other US institutions (e.g. Scripps in Ja Jolla, California) and with international colleagues from Mexico.
